title: ArcBridge How-To
summary: Use this guide to navigate every core workflow in ArcBridge.
content:
ArcBridge helps you ingest **Guild Wars 2 arcdps logs**, analyze combat performance, and share outputs with your squad.

## How to use this guide

- Use the **Guide Map** on the left to jump by area.
- Use the **breadcrumbs** at the top to move up/down the hierarchy.
- Start with **Getting Started** for setup, then move to **Dashboard**, **Stats View**, and **Sharing**.

> Tip: For troubleshooting, jump to the **Troubleshooting** node at any time.

children.title: Getting Started
children.summary: Initial setup, first upload flow, and what to expect.
children.content:
## Setup checklist

- Open ArcBridge and set your **Log Directory** to your `arcdps.cbtlogs` folder.
- Confirm uploads are pointed at your intended output path (Discord mode, Web mode, or both).
- Optionally add your `dps.report` user token in Settings.

## First ingest workflow

1. Configure the log directory.
2. Add one or more `.zevtc` files (manual or watched ingestion).
3. Wait for status transitions (`queued -> uploading -> success`, or error states).
4. Verify fight cards include metadata (fight name, time, links, and computed details).

## Common first-run checks

- If no logs appear, verify the folder path and permissions.
- If uploads fail, review status text and your webhook/token configuration.
- If details are delayed, wait for parsing and aggregation to complete.

children.title: Dashboard
children.summary: Operational view for ingest, statuses, and per-fight actions.
children.content:
## What the Dashboard is for

The Dashboard is your **live operations surface** for fight ingestion and quick review.

## Key areas

- **Configuration panel**: log directory, upload mode, webhook selection.
- **Fight cards**: per-fight status, details, and action buttons.
- **Batch controls**: select/add many logs and process in bulk.

## Best practices

- Use batch adds for session analysis to avoid fragmented samples.
- Treat status text as authoritative for upload health.
- Open fight cards to inspect details before sharing.

children.title: Stats View
children.summary: Deep analysis of aggregated session performance.
children.content:
## Purpose

Stats View combines selected logs into a single **session-level analysis layer**.

## What you can inspect

- **Overview trends** across all selected fights.
- **Offense and defense** distribution patterns.
- **Support and utility** contributions.
- **Top players and top skills** by configured metrics.
- **Timeline/context sections** for progression over time.

## Interpretation guidance

- Use aggregated metrics for strategy calls, not single-fight variance.
- Compare multiple sections together (offense + support + defense) before drawing conclusions.
- Re-check stat mode toggles in Settings to ensure rankings match your intent.

children.title: Sharing
children.summary: Output workflows for Discord, screenshots, and web reports.
children.content:
## Sharing options

- **Discord Embed/Image**: fast in-chat delivery.
- **Stats screenshot export**: visual snapshot for announcements.
- **Web upload**: persistent, browsable report hosting.

## Choosing the right output

- Use Discord when your squad needs rapid summaries.
- Use web reports when you want historical links and richer browsing.
- Use screenshots for one-click, visual, low-friction communication.

## Reliability checks

- Validate webhook and token before high-volume posting.
- Confirm web publish URL resolves after upload/build completion.
- If output looks stale, re-run with fresh logs and confirm build status.

children.title: Settings & Integrations
children.summary: Central control for behavior, metrics, visuals, and integrations.
children.content:
## Settings categories

- **Appearance**: UI theme and visual presentation.
- **Upload/Auth**: tokens, webhook settings, connection state.
- **Stat behavior**: top-stat toggles, ranking mode, MVP weights.
- **Web publishing**: GitHub repository and Pages support.
- **Portability**: import/export settings snapshots.

## High-impact settings to review first

- `dps.report` user token
- Notification mode (`embed`, `image`, etc.)
- Top stats mode (`total` vs `perSecond`)
- MVP weighting model

## Maintenance workflows

- Export settings before major updates.
- Import settings to move between machines.
- Re-open Help & Updates for walkthroughs and release notes.

children.title: GitHub Web Reports
children.summary: Hosted report pipeline using GitHub repositories and Pages.
children.content:
## What is GitHub (for new users)?

**GitHub** is a website that stores project files in online folders called **repositories** (or "repos").

In ArcBridge, GitHub is used as your report hosting backend:

- ArcBridge uploads report files into a repo you choose.
- GitHub Pages then serves those files as a normal website URL.
- You share that URL with your squad.

Think of it as: ArcBridge = report builder, GitHub = report storage + website hosting.

## Why use this integration?

- Your reports live at a stable URL you can bookmark.
- Anyone with the link can view reports in a browser.
- You can keep consistent branding (theme/logo).
- You don't need to manually move report files around.

## Before you start

You need:

- A GitHub account.
- Permission to create or use a repository in that account.
- ArcBridge desktop app with GitHub integration enabled.

## High-level setup path

1. Connect ArcBridge to GitHub (authorization flow).
2. Pick an existing report repository or create a new one.
3. Confirm the GitHub Pages URL is set.
4. Choose a theme/logo (optional).
5. Upload a report and verify the published page.

## Key terms (quick glossary)

- **Repository (repo)**: an online folder for files.
- **Branch**: a version stream in a repo (usually `main`).
- **GitHub Pages**: GitHub's static website hosting.
- **Token/Auth**: permission ArcBridge needs to upload files for you.
- **Build status**: indicates whether Pages has finished publishing updates.

## Safety and ownership notes

- ArcBridge only works with the repo you select.
- If auth expires or permissions change, uploads can fail until reconnected.
- Keep your GitHub account secure (2FA recommended).

children.title: Connect & Authorize
children.summary: Authenticate and target the repository for publishing.
children.content:
## Step-by-step (beginner friendly)

### 1. Start connection in ArcBridge

- Open **Settings -> GitHub Web Reports**.
- Click the connect/authenticate action.
- ArcBridge will show a short verification code and a GitHub URL.

### 2. Complete verification on GitHub

- Open the provided GitHub verification page.
- Sign in to your GitHub account (if not already signed in).
- Enter the code shown by ArcBridge.
- Approve access when prompted.

After approval, ArcBridge should show a connected/authenticated state.

### 3. Choose where reports should be stored

You can either:

- Select an existing repository, or
- Create a new repository from ArcBridge.

If you're new, creating a dedicated repo just for reports is usually easiest.

### 4. Confirm repo details

Verify these values in Settings:

- **Owner**: your GitHub username or org.
- **Repository name**: target repo for report files.
- **Branch**: usually `main`.
- **Pages URL**: generated website URL used for sharing.

## First-time validation checklist

- Auth state says connected.
- Repo is selectable and saved.
- Pages URL appears.
- No current error banner in the GitHub section.

## Common beginner issues

- **Wrong account signed in**: sign out/in on GitHub and reconnect.
- **Repo not visible**: ensure permissions and refresh repo list.
- **Connection says error**: retry auth; token may be expired/revoked.
- **Pages URL missing**: wait for repo setup/template steps, then retry.

children.title: Theme & Branding
children.summary: Set report visuals and keep published branding consistent.
children.content:
## What this section controls

- **Web theme**: visual style/colors/layout for published reports.
- **Logo**: image shown in your report branding area.
- **Template sync**: ensures the hosted report structure is up to date.

## Recommended beginner workflow

1. Connect GitHub and select repo first.
2. Choose your theme in ArcBridge.
3. Optionally select a logo file.
4. Apply/sync changes.
5. Wait for build status to complete.
6. Open the Pages URL and confirm visuals.

## Logo guidance

- Prefer a clean PNG or SVG with transparent background.
- Avoid extremely large files.
- If logo looks stretched, try a square or balanced aspect ratio.

## How to verify your changes

- Build status should move from pending/checking to success.
- Refresh the published URL in browser after build finishes.
- Confirm theme colors and logo match what you selected.

## If customization doesn't show up

- Re-run apply theme/logo.
- Confirm repo/branch are correct.
- Check build status for errors.
- Hard-refresh browser cache on the report URL.

children.title: Troubleshooting
children.summary: Rapid diagnosis path for ingest, stats, and publish failures.
children.content:
## Quick triage sequence

1. Re-check log directory path and read permissions.
2. Confirm webhook/token/repository values in Settings.
3. Review status banners for parse/upload/build errors.
4. Retry with a known-good small log set.

## Symptom-based hints

- **No logs detected**: path mismatch or watcher not active.
- **Upload errors**: invalid webhook/token or transient network/API issue.
- **Missing stats sections**: check stat toggles and whether logs completed processing.
- **Web report stale**: verify template/theme sync and Pages build status.

## Escalation

Use [Support Discord](https://discord.gg/UjzMXMGXEg) and include:

- A short symptom summary
- Steps to reproduce
- Relevant status messages
